emailColumn.title: drinkit: Real International Expansion Lessons

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Kate Borodich is an international expansion expert at Dodo Brands, a tech-driven foodservice franchise company with 1000+ locations across 21 countries. She previously worked on Dodo Pizza's expansion in England and now leads the international market development for drinkit, the company's digital-first coffee shop concept. Dodo Brands crossed $1 billion in system-wide sales in 2024 and is known for its transparent operations and innovative franchise model.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: International expansion requires extreme preparation and realistic expectations. Success comes from small, focused teams (3-5 people) that prioritize the 20% of tasks delivering 80% of results. Dubai serves as an excellent franchise showcase due to its visa-free access, transport hub status, and presence of global competitors. The key to success is methodical audience building, continuous adaptation, and treating expansion as a long-term battle rather than a quick win. Even experienced businesses must relearn their skills in new markets, but with proper preparation and persistence, profitability is achievable within the first month.

emails.subject: Warning: International Expansion Isn't Easy - Hard Truths Before You Start
emails.body:
Next letters are going to be about our experience of üçï drinkit & [dodo brands](https://dodobrands.io). But before that I have to say great warning for businesses that are going international.

Some businessmen who haven't yet ventured into other markets think that it's not difficult, it's not scary, and you can give it a try. And I'll build the business here within 2 months. That's not true. ‚ùå

It is painful, scary, and you need to think 300 times before doing it. Then calculate 200 times whether you have enough üí∞ money for it, and then think again. I've seen a lot of businesses that entered Dubai thinking it's easy and now they're leaving disappointed with big financial losses. üìâ

Entering foreign markets is not a walk in the park üå≥, it's a battle ‚öîÔ∏è, a long one, and it's tough. You're entering a place where you don't know the rules, the culture, you practically know nothing. It's like you're rediscovering the üåç world. Even if you know how to build businesses in your home country, here you're literally relearning that skill. It's like learning to walk again after an injury. üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

That's probably the first super important point. ‚ö†Ô∏è

Even though it's tough, it's still possible. ‚úÖ

Next letter we're moving directly to us.

highlight.title: Reality Check: International Expansion is a Battle
highlight.description: Many businesses underestimate international expansion, thinking it's quick and easy. The truth is it requires extreme preparation, significant financial resources, and the mindset that you're essentially starting over. Even successful domestic businesses must relearn their skills in new markets. It's not a 2-month project - it's a long-term battle that requires thinking 300 times and calculating finances 200 times before starting.

emails.subject: Ready to Expand: Why We Chose Global from Day One

highlight.title: Global Vision from Day One
highlight.description: Having a global vision from the start makes international expansion feel natural rather than forced. When you see your business model working at home and in nearby markets, it builds confidence to try new territories. The key is testing the waters first - Dodo Brands tested in Kazakhstan before Dubai, and used a joint location approach to reduce risk while proving the concept works internationally.

emails.subject: Franchise Strategy Works Great in Dubai - Why We Chose the UAE
emails.body:
Here are some words concerning quite a crucial part of a successful franchise.

We were considering the whole world ([Dodo Brands](https://dodobrands.io) already had restaurants in America, China, and Europe). Dubai, based on many factors, was the most convenient and suitable for placing what you could call a franchise showcase. üè™

Dubai is not only good for taxes and the speed of opening a business, but it's also a transport hub ‚Äî you can come to Dubai without a visa. ‚úàÔ∏è People often fly through Dubai. For America you need a visa, for some European countries you need a Schengen visa. Dubai is visa-free, and we understand that drinkit is a franchise, and it's mainly a business. üíº It's very important for us to show as many people as possible our locations.

It was clear that if we entered a country where all the major global players are present, and we learned to compete with them, we'd refine the drinkit concept to compete better in other countries. üèÜ It was more of a high-level strategic analysis. I don't remember comparing GDP, Taxes, or some other parameters.

We specifically chose not to set strict deadlines or success metrics for the Dubai launch, preferring to adapt as we learned. üìä

That's all for now,

highlight.title: Dubai as a Franchise Showcase Strategy
highlight.description: Dubai works perfectly as a franchise showcase because it's visa-free, acts as a transport hub, and hosts all major global competitors. This means potential franchisees can easily visit to see your concept in action, while competing against top players helps refine your business model. It's not just about tax benefits - it's about accessibility and learning from the best competition in the world.

emails.subject: The Team of Three People - Small Team, Big Results
emails.body:
It's reasonable to let you know some features about our team. And maybe you will be impressed by the fact that the international market is handled by a team of three people. 3Ô∏è‚É£ They are: me, Vova Garipov, who is responsible for the drink-and-food menu and the PM Anastasia Nikitina I'd hired.

I was already working on [Dodo Pizza](https://dodobrands.io) in England before. When you launch a physical business abroad, there are a lot of diverse tasks that just need to be done: finding spoons ü•Ñ, finding lids for cups, connecting to wiring ‚ö°, setting up an SMS provider üì±, printing flyers üìÑ. A ton of things you need to do to launch a physical business. And it looks attractive to hire a big team to get all the tasks done. But instead of doing all the tasks, you need to launch the business. üöÄ

My recipe of perfect setup for startup:
‚Ä¢ Small team 3-5 people üë•
‚Ä¢ Choose 20% the most important tasks which will bring you 80% of the result üìä
‚Ä¢ and nail it for 100% üíØ

So, essentially, it was a new team formed for drinkit. Three people ‚Äî it's not a huge resource but enough to launch the business. ‚úÖ

Best regards,

highlight.title: The Power of Small, Focused Teams
highlight.description: A small team of 3-5 people can be more effective than a large team for international expansion. The key is focusing on the 20% of tasks that deliver 80% of results rather than trying to do everything. When launching a physical business abroad, it's tempting to hire big teams for all the small tasks, but the goal is to launch the business, not to perfectly complete every task.

emails.subject: No Mistakes, Just Lessons Learned - Our Dubai Experience
emails.body:
This letter I will answer your direct question "What mistakes do you think you made when entering Dubai?" ü§î

Not everything is perfect, of course. Maybe I'd say these aren't mistakes but lessons learned in Dubai. üìñ

There were definitely hiring lessons, a bad hire. Generally speaking, we hired a very lazy guy. üò¥

We were close to investing into manufacturing at an early stage. But these aren't mistakes of entering Dubai.

When you run a business, you learn lessons along the way. You always find the right keys üîë to the audience and build the model correctly.

We immediately found our audience. But the lesson here is that you need to constantly, very methodically, win over the audience ‚Äî the market is very competitive. üèÅ For example, I see that revenues in Marina (our first location) are doubling compared to last year. üìà You build your client base through hard work, a great product, and excellent service. It's more about building relationships. ü§ù

We introduced one drink ü•§, then expanded, then introduced food üçï. Now we're looking for the right keys to the food. These are the lessons we're learning.

The same goes for economics. For drinkit, we see that we need to adjust the models to reach the target economics. If we're talking about breaking even, our first location in Marina broke even in the first month. üí∞

Thank you for your attention! üôè

highlight.title: Learning Through Methodical Audience Building
highlight.description: International expansion is about continuous learning rather than avoiding mistakes. The key lessons include being careful with hiring, methodically winning over audiences in competitive markets, and gradually expanding offerings (drinks first, then food). Success comes from building relationships through hard work, great products, and excellent service. Even first-month profitability is possible with the right approach.

highlight.title: The Complete International Expansion Framework
highlight.description: Successful international expansion follows a clear framework: extreme preparation and financial planning, small focused teams for execution, methodical audience building and continuous adaptation, and strategic market selection that forces you to compete with the best. The result is concept refinement that benefits all future markets, proven by achieving first-month profitability and doubling revenues through persistent optimization.
